answers.author: Eric Johnson
answers.text:
Here is an idea: You want to end up with something different but still complying with the Distinguished Budget Presentation Award Program criteria. So you want to limit your search to compliant budgets. Fortunately, there are a lot. Second, you want to quickly figure out who is unique. To get there, you might contact those who see a lot of them: reviewers for the program. You can find the list here: http://www.gfoa.org/sites/default/files/u63/GFOAreviewersofbudgetdocumentsforthe2013calendaryear%284%29.pdf
Look up email addresses at their jurisdictions' web sites and contact a few reviewers to see if they have any favorites to recommend. I've been reviewing budgets for a very long time but actually haven't seen much in terms of the departmental presentation to suggest -- but other reviewers might. Based on an earlier response you received, I looked at the City of Wichita document and it is really a nice approach to presenting departmental information -- good use of a standard format, embedded photos, and use of color to enhance the presentation and encourage a reader to actually read it! I like how they tie their performance measures to specific benchmarking organizations. 
I also looked at Loudoun's document. I typically review large counties' budgets, like your county, and I noticed that your document is lengthy -- about 425 pages in the departmental section alone. One consideration I would suggest would be to set an objective to shrink the detail and shorten the document. The current level of detail could be make available elsewhere on your website -- like at a department's own web site. Here is my rationale: if the document is too large, it will intimidate most potential users. An approach is to roll up to a higher level in the budget document and list key objectives and measures rather than drill down to the current level of detail. If you then apply a Wichita approach for an enhanced presentation, it doesn't have to be replicated for 425 pages. Feel free to contact me directly if you have any questions.

author: Ben Carbajal
text: I am working on a project for Loudoun County Government to find innovative and accessible ways of representing information within our budget documents while maintaining GFOA standards. I have seen examples from Walnut Creek, California and Arlington, Massachusetts. We currently present information via a narrative/table format and can be viewed here: http://www.loudoun.gov/index.aspx?NID=2857.  If you believe you have a unique way of presenting your information or know of another jurisdiction that does, please contact me at ben.carbajal@loudoun.gov. I appreciate your help! Ben Carbajal
title: Ways to Present Information in Budget Documents
